msItem.title: Liber de aggregationibus scientie stellarum
Liber Alfragani Tiberiadis secundum translationem grecam credo.
msItem.incipit: Numerus mensium anni arabum et aliorum omnium est 12 menses
msItem.rubric: Capitulum primum de annis arabum et aliorum omnium et nominibus mensium ipsorum et dierum eorum et diversitate earum adinvicem.
msItem.explicit: Jam ergo declaravimus de eclipsibus Solis et Lune quod sufficit intelligenti.
msItem.author: Alfraganus

msItem.title: Liber de aggregationibus scientie stellarum
Liber Alfragani Tiberiadis secundum translationem grecam credo.
msItem.incipit: Numerus mensium anni arabum et aliorum omnium est 12 menses
msItem.rubric: Capitulum primum de annis arabum et aliorum omnium et nominibus mensium ipsorum et dierum eorum et diversitate earum adinvicem.
msItem.explicit: Jam ergo declaravimus de eclipsibus Solis et Lune quod sufficit intelligenti.
msItem.author: Alfraganus

msItem.title: Lectiones tabularum Toletanarum secundum Arzachelis, Canones Ca
Incipiunt Lectiones tabulraum Toletanarum secundum Arrachiel scilicet Hyspanus secundum rationem Caldeorum.
msItem.incipit: In domine Domini. Scito quod annus lunaris sit ex 354 diebus
msItem.explicit: erit dies revolutionis priusquam dies radices ex hoc mense duobus diebus.
msItem.author: Azarchel

msItem.title: De apparitione Lune
msItem.incipit: De Lune apparitione competens est notare
msItem.explicit: statum presentis regionis accipiantur. Amen. Explicit. Deo gratias.
msItem.author: Anonymous

msItem.title: Canones and tabulas Toletanas, Canons Cb
Canones tabularum astronomie Azarchelis.
msItem.incipit: Quoniam cujusque actionis quantitas tempore quantitatem tempus metitur celestium motuum doctrinam
msItem.explicit: per quas horas inveniessignum oriens ascendens et ejus gradum sicut ostensum est in precedentibus. Expliciunt Canones tabularum Toletanarum.
msItem.author: Azarchel

msItem.title: Excerpt of Canon Ca, Canon in latitudinibus 5 planetarum secundum Ptolomeum et Albategni
De latitudinibus planetarum aliter quam prius dictum sit.
msItem.incipit: Cum volueris scire latitudinem planetarum et ejus partem
msItem.explicit: vix tamen aliter quam ut diximus inqueri poterit. Explicit Canon in latitudinibus 5 planetarum secundum Ptholomeum et Albategny.
msItem.author: Anonymous

msItem.title: Excerpt from Canons for eclipses, De eclipsibus luminarium aliter quam prius dictum sit
msItem.incipit: In regionibus quibus accidit diversitas secundum aspectum
msItem.explicit: eclipsis Solis durare per horam unam vel dimidiam, cum constet dyametrum Solis esse magis quam duplum ad dyametrum terre.
msItem.author: Anonymous

msItem.title: Expositio supra canones Arzachelis
Expositio Jo.de Silicia [sic] supra canones Arzachelis, facta Parisius anno Christi 1290 perfecto.
msItem.incipit: Cum inter cetera philosophice documenta
msItem.explicit: sed BN et EG sunt equales cum utraque si assumatur NE.
msItem.author: Johannes de Sicilia

msItem.title: Almanach planetarum
Guillelmus de Sancto Clodoaldo, anno Domini 1290 [sic].
msItem.incipit: Cum intentio mea sit componere almanac planetarum
msItem.explicit: dicit enim in humanis inventionibus nichil reor esse perfectum.
msItem.author: Guillelmus de Sancto Cloadoaldo

msItem.title: Kalendarium regine
Kalendarium regine M. per G. de Sancto Clodoaldo.
msItem.incipit: Testante Vegeti libro suo De re militari antiquis temporibus
msItem.explicit: sicut dictum est de primo climate sic feci de aliis 6 climatibus.
msItem.author: Guillelmus de Sancto Clodoaldo

msItem.title: Fragment of the end of an unidentified text.
msItem.explicit: et eam addes primo extremo si minor fuerit 2o, vel substrahes si primum extremum majus fueri.
msItem.author: Anonymous

msItem.title: Expositio intentionis regis Alfontii circa tabula ejus
Expositio intentionis regis Alfonsii circa tabula ejus.
msItem.incipit: Alfonsius Castelle, rex illustris, florens ingenio
msItem.explicit: qui pro tacenda veritate nec flecti prece, nec obliquari munere dignarentur. Completum est hoc opus anno et die supradictis. Amen.
msItem.author: Johannes de Muris

msItem.title: Kalendarium anno Christi 1320
Kalendarium Gaufredi de Meldis anno Christi 1320.
msItem.incipit: Cunctis Solis et Lune scire desiderantibus vera loca
msItem.explicit: quo habito alia festa mobilia de facili possunt sciri.
msItem.author: Gaufredus de Meldis

msItem.title: Theorica planetarum
Theorica planetarum a J. de Lineriis, anno Christi 1335o.
msItem.incipit: Spera concentrica vel circulus concentricus dicitur
msItem.explicit: et ex duplici motu secundum partes oppositas in suo deferente ut decaratum est. Explicit Theorica planetarum magistri Johannis de Lineriis, anno Christi.
msItem.author: Johannes de Lineriis

msItem.title: Tractatus super defectibus tabularum Alfontii
Expositio tabularum Alfonsii et motiva probantia falsitatem earum.
msItem.incipit: Bonum quidem mihi videtur omnibus nobis astrorum
msItem.explicit: zelo ut ab errorum devio retraham hanc scientiam inquirentes. Explicit. Factum anno Domini 1347, 20a die aprilis, credo per Gaufredum de Meldis.
msItem.author: Anonymous

msItem.title: Canones tabularum Alfontii
Canones tabularum Alfonsii, regis Castelle, per Jo.de Lineriis.
msItem.incipit: Quia ad inveniendum loca planetarum
msItem.explicit: sit 3a signa complete 2 per 12o ante vel retro dic eclipsim Lune possibilem in illo mense.
msItem.author: Johannes de Lineriis

msItem.title: Canones tabularum astronomie
Secundus liber canonum m.Jo. de Lineriis, super tabulas primi mobilis.
msItem.incipit: Cujuslibet arcus propositi sinum rectum per tabulas invenire
msItem.explicit: quousque concordat cum vero ejus qui fuit in radice et habebis propositum.
msItem.colophon: Expliciunt Canones tabularum astronomie per magistrum Johannem de Lineriis, ordinati Parisius, completi anno Christi 1320mo, in civitate Cameraci scripti etc
msItem.author: Johannes de Lineriis

msItem.title: Canones super tabulas magnas
Canones super tabulas magnas per Jo. De Lineriis compilatas [adding from the second copyist: ad meridianum Parisiensem] ex tabulis Alfonsii.
msItem.incipit: Multiplicis philosophie variis radiis illustrato domino Roberto de Florencia
msItem.explicit: et habebis verum tempus conjunctionis vel oppositionis, diebus equatis.
msItem.author: Johannes de Lineriis

msItem.title: Canones eclipsium
Canones eclipsium Jo. De Janua.
msItem.incipit: Ad sciendum eclipsim Solis, primo quere
msItem.explicit: vide in Albategni et in canonibus magistri Jo. De Lineriis, quia magis prolixum est quam difficile et ideo de hoc ad presens supersedeo. Expliciunt Canones eclipsium quos compilavit magister Jo. De Janua, extrahendo eos est partim a canonibus communibus, partim a minori Almagesti, partim a magistro Jo.de Cecilia in scripto suo super tabulas Toletanas, specialiter quantum ad puncat eclipsis minuta casus et dimidie more, anno Christi 1332 incompleto, 22a die januarii.
msItem.author: Johannes de Janua

msItem.title: Canone tabule ad sciendum motum Solis et Lune in una hora et semidiametros luminarium secundum tabulas Alfontii
msItem.incipit: Verum motum Solis et Lune in una hora et semidyametros Solis et Lune et umbre tempore conjunctionis et oppositionis per hanc tabulam invenire
msItem.explicit: nec est differentia in alio non video necessitatem repetendi. Explicit de eclipsibus.
msItem.author: Johannes de Janua

msItem.title: Investigatio eclipsis Solis anno Christi 1337o
Investigatio eclipsim Solis anno Christi 1337o per Jo. de Janua.
msItem.incipit: Ad investigandum eclipsim Solis, oportet primo quere
msItem.explicit: et idem tempus duplavi et provenit duratio eclipsis 2.3.54.16 [sic]. Explicit doctrina ad inveniendum eclipsim Solis anno Domini 1337, 2a die martii, data a magistro Joh. De Saxonia Janua et per conseqeuns aliarum.
msItem.author: Johannes de Janua

msItem.title: Canones tabularum Oxonie anno Christi 1348, ex tabulis Alfonsii factarum
msItem.incipit: Vera loca omnium planetarum in longitudine
msItem.explicit: qui in casu parvus accidit nullus est ut dictum est. Explicit totum opus tabularum Oxonie que facte sunt super tabulas Alfonsii.
msItem.author: Anonymous

msItem.title: Canones supra tabulas Alfontii
Canones Jo. de Saxonia supra tabulas Alfonsii, regis Castelle.
msItem.incipit: Tempus est mensura motus, ut vult Aristoteles 4to Phisicorum
msItem.explicit: expliciunt Canones super tabulas magnas illustrissimi Castelle regis Alfoncii per Johannem de Counnout, alias de Saxonia, editi anno Domini 1327, magistri Jo. de Lineriis discipulum Parisius.
msItem.author: Johannes de Saxonia

msItem.title: Exempla super tabulas primi mobilis et canones Johannis de Lineriis
Exempla Jo. de Saxonia super tabulas primi mobilis et canones Jo. de Lineriis.
msItem.incipit: Quia plures astrologorum diversos libros fecerunt
msItem.explicit: ascendens ut prius invenies hora tue considerationis ut supra in 36a hujus dicitur, et sic finis.
msItem.colophon: Ego scriptor huius Jo.B complevi hunc canonem, et sic est finis operationum que fiunt circa tabulas conjonctionum et eclipsium luminarium.
msItem.author: Johannes de Saxonia

msItem.title: Tractatus astronomicus
msItem.incipit: Centrum est cujus ab initio circumductio
msItem.explicit: secundum similitudinem ejus quod fecimus in hiis que precesserunt.
msItem.author: Johannes de Troyes

msItem.title: Tractatus de commensurabilitate vel incommensurabilitate motuum celi
Tractatus de commensurabilitate motuum celi.
msItem.incipit: Zenonem et Crisippum majora egisse affirmat Seneca
msItem.explicit: et ipse prorsus nescio quid super hoc judex decrevit Apollo. Explicit hic Tractatus de commensuratione motuum.
msItem.author: Nicolaus Oresmus

msItem.title: Modus componendi almanac.
msItem.incipit: In almanac componendo sic procede
msItem.explicit: et quando Sol mutat signum.
msItem.author: Anonymous

msItem.title: Tabula
Tabula magistri Jacobi de Partibus.
msItem.incipit: Sequuntur sirupi ad omnes humores
msItem.explicit: Medicine ad idem: anthos / naturcii / amieos. Explicit Tabula magistri Jacobi de Partibus.
msItem.author: Jacobus de Partibus

support.watermark: The watermarks locates on the folio 16r, 138v, 139r (letter with "P" with fleuron), are closed to Briquet n°8593.
Others watermarks are situated on the folio 245r, 246r, 248r, 253r, 255r, 256r, 258r.

supportDesc.extent:
283 leaves of paper, preceded by three unfoliated paper flyleaves at the beginning, and three at the end.
240 170 30 35 20 45
supportDesc.foliation: Foliation written by Jo.B (mid-15th century). Misfoliation: the folio 164r has been repeted twice and the folio 205r has been delete.
supportDesc.collation:
29 Quires: iii + 114(ff.1r-14v) + 12(ff.15r-16v) + 112(ff.17r-28v) + a flyleaf mounted on paper tab (f.29r) + 116(ff.30r-45v) ; a slip of paper mounted on paper tab ( f.32 bis), paper tab located between ff. 35r and 36r; a slip of paper mounted on paper tab (f.33 bis), paper tab located between ff. 41r and 42r; a slip of paper mounted on a paper tab (f.39 bis), paper tab located between ff. 42r and 43r + 112(ff.44r-57v) + 112(58r-69v) + 112(70r-81v) + a 16th-century ‘s leaf of paper folded in two inserted between the leaf 69r and 70r + 112(82r-93v) + a slip of paper (f.82bis) mounted on a paper tab between ff.85v-86r a short slip of paper (f.85bis) has been mounted on the same tab between ff. 85r-86r + a slip of paper (f.89bis) mounted on a paper tab between (ff.92v-93r) + 112(94r-105v) + 112(ff.106r-117v) + 112(ff.118r-129v) + 111(ff.130r-140v), a slip of paper (f.136bis) mounted on a paper tab between ff.140r-141r; + 13(ff.141r-143v) + a paper tab inserted between (ff.143r-144r) + 16(ff.144r-149v) + 16(ff.150r-155v) + 16(ff.156r-161v) + 13(ff.162r-164v) + 110(ff.165r-174v) + 110 (ff.177r+ 186v) + 110(ff.189r-198v)+ 112(ff.199r-210v) + f.205 had been removed + 112(211r-222v) + 12(ff.223r-224v) + 110(ff.225r-234v) + a 16th-century bifolio inserted between (ff.234r-235r) and foliated 234bis-234ter + 112(ff.235r-246v) + 112(ff.247r-258v) + 112(ff.259r-270v) + 112(ff.271r-282v).

layoutDesc.layout: Most pages have around 40 lines of writing. Alternating dry point and lead point for the ruling.

handDesc.handNote: First copyist: hand of the 15th-century (around 1445-1460), belonging to the astronomer Jo. B, probably from Cambrai.
Second copyist: Mid-15th-century hand, probably contemporary to Jo. B’s hand, but which shows some slightly different features.
Third copyist: A later hand from the laster quarter of the fifteenth century.
First annotator: Hand A (Jo.B's Hand) which frequently annotates his own copy with a more abreviated handwriting.
Second annotator: Hand B. Handwriting from the third quarter of the 15th-century. The features have some Littera rotunda characteristics.Very abbreviated handwriting with stylized tildes.
Third annotator: Hand C. Handwriting from the very end of the 15th-century. Faded brown ink and use of a thin pen.
Fourth annotator: Hand D. Handwriting of the beginning of the 16th-century.

decoDesc.decoNote: On the folio 1r, decoration is incomplete given the guide letter: e.g: Guide letter for the letter “N”.Embellishment of the “s” on the word “lectiones” and kind of grotesques including zoomorphic figures on the letter “I” of“Incipiunt” on the folio 17r. Also red rubric and red letter on the folio 17r to 28v.

binding.decoNote: Binding of the Royal library (17th-century) with Royal arms.
Normal spine with raised bands. Title on the spine: "Tractatus Astrologie".

history.origin: This volume was certainly composed by Jo.B, given his monogram ,perhaps from Cambrai and intervening several time in the texts. All suggests that this manuscript was carefully elaborated by an expert in the field of astronomy, who aimed to gather several astronomical texts retracing all the innovations ranging from the 13th century to the 15th century.
history.provenance: The manuscript includes Louis le Puiset’s signature preceded by four lines partially erased.

Given the late 15th-century features of Louis le Puiset’s handwriting, he may have owned the codex slightly before or after Jehan Avis. Jehan purchased this manuscript in 1487 1487 for 20 sous parisis: Ce livre fut achetté par moy Jehan Avis, l’an 1487 imparfait, le 7eme de juillet, la somme de 20 s.p.We do not know from whom Jehan acquired this codex.

Then, Jean Avis may have lent the manuscript to Simon de Phares, during the latter’s stay in Paris between 1491 and 1492 when he was a familier of the bishop Louis de Beaumont de la Forêt. Simon de Phares attended the arts Faculty in Paris between 1462 and 1465. He was recorded as a physician in Parliament registers, but it is not certain that he held a grade in medicine (cf. J-P Boudet, 1999, II, 55-63). He began his astrologer career in 1469 at Jean II de Bourbon’s Court. Acting as a professional astrologer especially at the Bourbon’s Court, he was finally condemned by the Faculty of theology the February 19, 1494 and the Parliament of Paris the March 26, 1494, and his eleven astrological books were confiscated.

Then the codex entered in the Colbert's library in the 17th century, (see Colbert’s shelfmark) Cod.Colbert 1827" and the note of Colbert’s librarian Ista versio diversa a versione que edita est Noribergae, anno 1537 et Parisius, anno 1546, apud bibliotheco D. Arnaudi Pratoris Forcalcaris. Both editions (Nuremberg, 1537 and Paris, 1546) refer to Johannes Hispalensis’s translation of the "De scientia stellarum", whereas the version contained in this manuscript is Gerardus Cremonensis’s translation.Jean-Baptiste Colbert developed his private library by purchasing printed books and manuscripts from institutions or individuals. In this enterprise, he was helped by his librarians, first Pierre de Carcavy and then Etienne Baluze. Since 1666, Etienne Baluze acquired several important manuscript collections from different places for Colbert. The minister’s private library became one of the most important collection of manuscripts and books in France. It is perhaps during Etienne Baluze appointment that BnF, Latin 7281 was purchased amongst other manuscript. Since 1683, Colbert’s library, located in rue Vivienne, was administered and increased by his first son Jean Baptiste, then by his second son Jacques-Nicolas Colbert. The library passed to their nephew Charles-Eléonor Colbert, comte de Seignelay, who auctions the library in 1728.
history.acquisition: In 1790, the Royal library entered in the legal deposit and became the National Library.The other revolutionary confiscations continued to enrich this library.

projectDesc.p: Elaboration of a fragmentary transcription of the Latin 7281 manuscript, according to the standards of the TEI XML format, standard of exchange or of document display allowing to separate the form and the contents and offering a declination of tool giving the possibility to exploit a text like a real database.

This editing work is part of the ERC Alfa research project dedicated to alphonsine astronomy.The objective of this project is to trace the development of the corpus of alphonsin texts from their origin at the end of the fifteenth century. Therefore, manuscripts are at the heart of Alfa's approach because they testify to the different intellectual practices of a given era.

The Latin 7281 manuscript is a major collection containing 27 astronomy treatises from the 9th to the 15th century. As part of this codex, it has proved interesting to focus more on annotations, tables, diagrams and inserted leaves which make it specific, rather than on the textual content itself which it have already been edited.

note.note: Typical reference signs: simple dots.
Paragragph number.

div.note: Ex solis altitudine horas diei praesentis extrahere. Sinum altitudinis solis praesentis in sinum medietatis arcus diei multiplica [...] Hec demonstrantur per katam coniunctam a Ptolomaeo traditam in fine capituli 12'i dictionis (?), adiuvante 15'a 5'ti Euclidis.The annotator explains Blabla blibli
In hoc libro nihil invenitur de motu 8'ae sphaerae, quod mirum videtur.Reference to the absence of the movement of the 8th sphere.

Secundum Albategni verius fit aequatio veri loci lunae aequando portionem lunae sic [...]Jo.B is quoting inter alia Albategni’s Opus astronomicum related to the equation of the Lunar true longitude, and the way to comput a Lunar portion.

note.note: He continues his statement by saying that this can be found in Albategni and in Canon Ca, which corresponds to Ptolemy’s demonstration in the Almagest.

div.note: Has tabulas composuit Abensahet, judex regis Maymon Toleto, cujus discipulus Azarchel et alii cum eo, sed Azarchel regebat instrumenta et dirigebat considerations. Postquam a Toleto dictus rex fuit expulsus a Chritianis, Azarchel ruit Cordube et ibi fecit et invenit novas considerationes et fecit tractatum de motu Solis et stellarum fixarum. Post venit Alcamet, discipulus ejus, [marg. similiter discipulus Messalle] et fecit tabulas persianas et quatuor paria tabularum. Post ipsum venit Albubalet Cordubensis, qui consideravit apud Murciam et ipse complevit radices ( ?) et tabulas conjunctionis Solis.Jo.B wrote a short biography of Azarchel. This annotation has probably inspired the notice of Simon de Phares’s, Recueil, III, 66b and VI, 125a.

Anno Christi 1291: in meridie primi diei Jan. fuerunt anni Arabum perfecti 689, et fuit radix 244159, feria 3'a; in meridie 2'ae diei Jan. fuerunt anni Persarum perfecti 659, feria 4'a. Et cum annus Christi 1292 incepit ultima die Decembris in meridie, annus Arabum 690 incepit in meridie primae Jan., et annus Persarum 660 incepit in meridie 2'ae diei Jan.He wrote also a statement explaining the concordance between the Christian, Arabic and Persian years taking the example of 1291.

Sunt canon(es) similes istis quantum ad principium et quantum ad processum, sed est differentia: Primo, quia non ponunt istum canonem de kardagis et declinationibus. Et pro sinibus utuntur chordis mediatis et tabula chordarum mediatarum secundum Ptolomaeum. (?) in canonibus (?) mobilis in aliquibus est differentia prout notavi in sequentibus. 4'o ponunt canonem latitudinum 5 planetarum secundum tabulam Ptolomaei. 5'o in aequatione diversitatis aspectus lunae et in aequatione eclipsium luminarium est differentia ut notavi in sequentibus et in quibusdam quae sequuntur. 6'o et finaliter non habent demonstrationem sinuum et arcuum et inventionem eorum et declinationis.Short canon on the Kardaga.

figure.figDesc: Two figures representing proportions.

div.note: Longitudo Toleti a Marsilia, ubi Ray(mun)dus est, per 1 horam et 10'am unius, videlicet 16 gra 30 m'a. Et Marsilia ab Arim distat 3 sic distat ab occidente 45 gra praecise, similiter a medio mundi. Note about the difference of longitude between Toledo, Marseille, Arim, Cremona, Toulouse, Novara, Paris, Aracta and Alexandria. He refers to Raymond of Marseille.

Et provenit argumentum latitudinis, cum quo eclipsim invenies, intrans cum eo tabulas Cordubenses, si volueris operari per eas. Vel si volueris operari cum tabulis Arzachelis, intrabis cum eo tabulas latitudinis lunae, et cum latitudine lunae ibi reperta intrabis tabulas Azarchelis. Intrabis ergo quam volueris cum eo, cum quo intrandum est, ad longitudinem longiorem vel propiorem vel in utramque etc. Ita habetur in aliis canonibus.Instructions for finding the argument of Lunar latitude.“Tabula Cordubensis” may refer to Canons Cc or to Alkhwarizmi’s tables.

figure.figDesc: Space left blank for a square diagram which had nevere been traced.
Another empty space for a diagram.
Figura Kardagarum.

div.note: Non plus erat de hoc in libro et repertum est antiquos canones etc;Instructions for finding the argument of Lunar latitude.“Tabula Cordubensis” may refer to Canons Cc or to Alkhwarizmi’s tables.

figure.figDesc: Fractions.

div.note: Secundum Albategni est 23 gra 35 m’a 31 2 etc.Recapitulating the different appreciations of the obliquity of the ecliptic, which the first two are quoted in text of John of Sicily’s commentary on Toledan tables canons: 23 n 51 'according to Ptolemy, 23°, 33', 30 'according to the al-Mâmûn astronomers, 23°, 35 '31’ according to Albategni, 23 ° 28 'according to' Monte Regio '.
Secundum De M onte Regio 23,28; per instrumenta moderna 23,30 “fere” secundum eudem.
Ex X’ a primi magnae constructionis quae Almagestum vocatur.
Secundum (?) Almagesti 11’a et 22’a epitomatis De R’Monte super Almagest., sed brevius per 24’am post 7’am.
Istud negandum est, quia nulla est similitude: patet in Theorica etcSmall leaf inserted with notes.
Secundum Alphonsium 287d. 0 h’e 24 m’a...
Si quem igitur delectet, experiatur tempore suo per instrumenta secundum doctriam a Ptolemaeo et De Regio Monte traditam in 14’a a propositione 3’i Almagesti.

Et haec secundum observationem Ptolemaei, ut ipse demonstrate in 3’a diction c. 7’mo; secundum vero considerationem Alphonsii maxima aequatio sive differentia inter etc. est 2 gra 10 m’a, quae est aequatio arcus 92 gra 10 m() motus aequalis, vel 90 gra motus apparentis.
Christi 1290, 8 menes 1d.
In theorica Planetarum habetur: Genzahar 3 superiorum immobiles sunt nisi quantum ad motum 8’ae sphaerae.

Nota, cum sol passurus est eclipsim, si totum esse illius eclipsis conspicere volueris sine oculorum laesione, scilicet quando incipit, quanta sit, quamdiu durat, quando finit, observa casum radii solis per medium alicuius foraminis rotundi facti in fenestra, et considera in assere circulum quem perficit radius solis super quem cadit. Cuius circuli rotunditatem cum videris deficere, eodem tempore deficit claritas in corpore solis, sed in parte opposita: ut si in circulo illo claritas incipit deficere ex parte orientis, tunc incipit sol eclipsari, sed ex parte occidentis. Et quot obscurabuntur partes diametrales illius circuli, tot digiti diametri solis eclipsantur. Et dum decrescit rotunditas circuli illius crescit eclipsis usque ad tantum, et dum recrescit rotunditas, descresit eclipsis, etc., ut dicit G. de Sancto Clodoaldo de quadam eclipsi solis anno Christi 1285. Potest idem probari per candelam ardentem etc.
Altitudo meridiana Solis Parisius, Sol in principio Cancri 640 44’ et Capricorni 170 36’. Maxima declination Solis: 23°24; latitude Parisiensis: 48050.

Circular diagram.
Circular diagram.
Circular diagram.

Diagram on the upper margin. Saint Cloud speaks about error which has been left in Mars’motion until the present time. According to him, the reason might be that it rarely happens that Mars is retrograde and closely passes a fixed star, once when direct and again when retrograde, as was the case in the two observations describe above. Further, in each observation it was close in latitude 1 to the star, so that the time of conjunction could be estimated precisely enough without an instrument.
Diagram about the camera obscura on the lower margin.

div.note: Iste Guillelmus probavit et bene vidit ad oculum quod tabule antique de motibus Ptholomei, Alexandri et Toletane et Tolosane et alie etc.non continent veritatem in motibus planetarum et 8espere. Ideo ex se correxit aliquos medios motus ut melius vidit, et potuit ad oculum addendo vel subtrahendo, et quia sic se sustentavit super illias et non fuit certus unde ille error processit vel ex omnibus illis, vel aliquibus eorum, ut apparet ex suis scriptis. Nec habuit notitiam tabularum Alfonsi que corrigunt defectus hujusmodi tabularum, quia nondum erant in manus hominum.Ideo suum Almanac sic factum et similter Kalendarium ejus defectum continent tabulraum et imprecisionem, quia non consistunt super verra correctione. Licet non forte tantum quantum tabule porpter suam corretcionem, sed quia grossa estimatione processit, ideo non est confidendum in illis Note about the interest in Saint Cloud’s corrections compared to the Toledan tables and the Toulouse tables, and his ignorance about the alphonsine tables.

note.note: Jo.B marked "addidi" in front of the part of this second table related to the years, which seems to place approximately its annotation between these two dates.

figure.figDesc: Table intitled "Tabularum latitudinis 7 climatum".
Table given the day and time of the entrance of the sun in the signs of the zodiac in 1296.
Table given the day and time of the entrance of the sun in the signs of the zodiac for the years 1296 to 1496.
Several tables made by Jo.B. Most of them are intented to update the Kalendarium.

div.note: Ista reperi in quondam libro etc.

Per Joh annem de Muris credo; mirum videtur quod iste non determinavit de quantitate eccentricitatum deferentis Solis et aliorum planetarum et de quantitate epiciclorum, consequenter de quantitate equationum argumenti Solis, centri et argumenti etc. ceteris planetis convenientium secundum intentionem regis Alfonsii quia alias et differentes posuit ab antiquis, prospecto quod de istis fuit semper diversitas inter consideratores.J.b Jo.B's note with his monogram. He says that the treatise was written by John of Murs and shows that he understood the importance of that work.
Tables made by Jo.B to update the Kalendarium.

note.note: Jo.B notes also the 120 possible planetary conjunctions: 21 conjunctions of two planets, 35 of three planets, 35 of four planets, 21 of five planets, 7 of six planets, 1 of seven planets.

person.occupation: Astronomer and astrologer. He served the caliph Abbassid al-Ma'mūn.
Astronomer, mathematician.
Librarian of Colbert (from 1667). Professor of Canon Law at the College de France. Royal College Inspector.Annotator and publisher of the works of saint Cyprien.
Advisor to the Parliament of Toulouse, the to the Grand Council. Guard of the King's Library since 1663. Member of the Royal Academy of Sciences since 1666.
Lord of Seignelay
Son of Jean-Baptiste Colbert (1619-1683), Minister of State. Ecclesiastical. Archbishop of Rouen. Member of the Institute, French Academy (elected in 1678).

Statesman, economist and patron. Minister of State (1661-1683). Superintendent of Royal Buildings, Arts and Manufactures (1664), Comptroller General of Finance (1695). Secretary of State, in charge of the King's House, the City of Paris, the Clergy and the Navy (1669). Member of the Institute, French Academy (elected in 1667).
Eldest son of Colbert (1619-1683). Collaborator and successor of his father at the State Secretariat in the Department of the Navy. Took part in several maritime expeditions.
Translator of scientific books from Arabic into Latin. One of Gerardus Cremonensis most famous translations is Ptolemy's Almagest from Arabic texts found in Toledo.

Astronomer close to queens Marie de Brabant and Jeanne de Navarre to whom he dedicates the French version of his Kalendarium regine and Utilitas instrumenti quod directorium appellatur. Author of several star tables and some other astronomical treatise (Almanach planetarum).His writting are located around 1291-1296.
Doctor.Chancellor of the University of Paris.
Dean of the faculty of medicine of Paris, and Charles the seventh's physician and counselor.
Duke of Bourbon and Auvergne from 1456 to his death.

person.name: Jo.B
person.occupation: He was probably a master of arts, and had a strong expertise in astronomy.
Dominican.
Mathematician. Translated important works of medicine and philosophy from Arabic into Latin.

Astronomer, whose Canons of the Tables became a widely used book. The Canons, a collection of astronomical tables, was adopted as part of the required educational texts for second-year students at the University of Bologna in 1344.
Astronomer, mathematician and music theorist. Master of Arts from the University of Paris (1321).
Astronomer.Has taught at the University of Paris from 1327 to 1355.
Astronomer.
Ecclesiastic who was bishop of Paris from 1472 to his death.
Bishop of Lisieux. Philosopher of the later Middle Ages, who wrote influential works on economics, mathematics, physics, astrology,astronomy, philosophy and theology.
Astrologer. Author of the "Collection of the most famous astrologers and some learned men" composed between 1494 and 1498
